evaluations.notes: Michael’s first full day in residential treatment. CIWA-Ar sits at 10—mild to moderate withdrawal. He’s edgy, sweaty, and complaining of nightmares. No one’s shocked, least of all him. Med staff decides to keep him on a scheduled benzo, given his propensity to try to 'tough it out' until he can’t. Because we’re not into that ER field trip lifestyle, we’re nipping this in the bud.

Michael is oriented x3 but moody, with an undercurrent of anxiety. Denies suicidal ideation, but you can feel the tension radiating off him. Minimal eye contact, though he half-laughed when asked about future goals ('Not dying'— hey, at least he’s honest). This MSE confirms the need for integrated psych support; his mental armor is fraying in real time.

Michael’s diet for the past year? A beer-based food pyramid. Labs hint at borderline anemia. Dietician steps in with a high-protein meal plan. He’s unimpressed with the kale smoothies, but we’re unimpressed with his liver function, so call it a draw. We’ll be monitoring micronutrient levels because he’s basically been living off pub food and cheap liquor.

Michael complains about 'emotional baggage' from childhood. Takes a while to trust the therapist but eventually vents about his father’s drinking and how he swore he’d 'never be like that.' Surprise! He’s kinda exactly like that. Time to break the cycle through CBT-focused therapy. He’s reluctant but shows glimmers of insight when cornered with facts.

Michael is the classic tough-guy skeptic in group. Rolled his eyes when others shared but eventually admitted his own slip-ups. The group gave him an encouraging roast, which he surprisingly took in stride. He’s learning that vulnerability doesn’t always spell weakness. Clinician notes show potential for deeper engagement—if we can keep him from bolting at the first sign of real feelings.

Revealed Michael’s financial stress: lost his last job after too many 'late mornings'—go figure. Our resident case manager is hooking him up with job resources and exploring short-term disability coverage. It’s the grown-up version of 'tough love': let’s keep him off the streets and in therapy, not in some shady bar at 10 AM.

Michael’s spouse joined by phone. Tense conversation: she’s frustrated with his 'serial broken promises,' and he’s defensive about 'nagging.' Therapist quickly realized they both speak fluent exasperation. A glimmer of progress emerged when he admitted shame about failing to provide emotional support. Might need multiple sessions to see real movement. Better buckle up.

Michael mapped out triggers: certain bars, old drinking buddies, payday. The usual suspects. Brainstormed coping skills (like calling his sponsor) instead of making a U-turn into the nearest dive bar. This plan is robust enough that if he follows even half of it, he might keep his sobriety afloat. We’ll see if logic prevails over impulse.

Michael’s on a daily naltrexone regimen for cravings. Reports reduced urges, but also mild nausea. We’ll keep him on it, because the alternative is a scenic route back to the bottle. Doctor also checks for possible interactions with his blood pressure meds—no issues there. All hail small victories.

Approaching the end of residential stay. Michael’s setting up aftercare: IOP, sober living arrangement, plus weekly therapy. We hammered home the importance of consistent attendance—he can’t phone in his recovery. Spouse to help with accountability, but we recommended reinforcing that with actual peer support (because let’s face it, spouses can’t do it all).

Sarah’s opioid withdrawal is no joke. COWS score: 12—moderate. She’s jittery, sweaty, complaining that 'pain is everywhere.' Nurse tries to keep her comfy, but let’s be real: it’s going to be a bumpy ride. MAT consult is on deck; nobody’s letting her vanish into the throes of unmedicated detox.

Sarah’s psychosocial background: college dropout (due to 'anxiety issues'), sporadic employment, and a rotating cast of unsupportive friends who double as pill suppliers. She’s good at masking vulnerabilities, but under that polished exterior is someone who’s terrified of withdrawal. This evaluation highlights the need for stable social support, or she’ll revert to 'pills as coping method' 101.

Psych doc picks up on signs of anxiety and possible panic disorder—Sarah’s jitters go way beyond standard opioid withdrawal. We’re exploring an SSRI or non-habit-forming anxiolytic. She’s open to the idea, as she’s tired of living in a constant anxious haze. Chalk one up for motivation, at least for today.

Sarah is surprisingly chatty in group, recounting how her 'functional façade' crumbled once the prescriptions dried up. She resonates with others who share the same 'I’m fine' charade. Notably tearful but also receptive to feedback. The group sense is that she’s genuinely engaging—so let’s keep that momentum going, shall we?

Her brother attends. Turns out their mother also had a prescription pill problem. They share a eureka moment: it’s all too familiar. The session is emotional, but also clarifying—Sarah realizes she’s repeating generational patterns. This is the messy reality of family dynamics; at least we’re calling it out and attempting to break the chain.

Started buprenorphine-naloxone for cravings. So far, so good, minus some mild headaches she claims are 'worse than the withdrawal.' (We’re skeptical, but we’ll keep an eye on it.) The doc also initiated a low-dose SSRI for anxiety. Because an anxious mind plus opioid cravings is a recipe for relapse flambé.

Sarah’s finances are a wreck, partly due to pill expenses and partly due to sporadic employment. She’s never budgeted a day in her life. We’re referring her to a life-skills workshop. If she doesn’t learn to handle stress and money the grown-up way, she’s just going to hop back on the pill train.

Sarah identifies her 'people, places, things'—the trifecta of triggers. We hammered out a plan: avoid old pill-peddling contacts, block those dealers’ numbers, lean on supportive peers instead of the 'friend' who offers a free fix. The document is a living blueprint for not swirling down the opiate drain again.

One week into IOP, Sarah’s still wrestling with cravings but claims they’re 'a notch lower.' She’s attending group consistently, which for her is a minor miracle. We’ll need more time to see if she’s truly committing or just biding time. Still, a glimmer of hope beats total radio silence.

Sarah’s nearing the end of her structured program. Transitioning to a lower level of care with continued MAT. Got a referral for ongoing therapy and possible job coaching because 'unemployed and bored' is a prime environment for relapse. Let’s see if she can do this without the crutch of daily supervision.

David’s tox screen lights up for cocaine, amphetamines, and traces of THC. This aligns with his self-reported 'party benders.' No major shockers here. He’s fatigued and sporting that classic stimulant crash face—think raccoon eyes minus the cute factor. We’ll proceed with partial hospitalization, because once he rebounds, the cravings will be fierce.

The psych doc notices signs of underlying anxiety. David swears he only uses stimulants to 'stay focused'—a likely ADHD self-diagnosis. We’re screening him for actual ADHD as well as possible personality issues. Medication might be on the horizon, but first we need to unravel the giant knot of his stimulant habit plus mental health disclaimers.

David’s first CBT session reveals he’s not just 'partying'; he’s running from anxiety, boredom, you name it. He jokes that partying is his version of 'extreme sports.' The therapist kindly points out that his track record suggests more self-destruction than adrenaline junkie. This is a classic amuse-bouche for deeper therapy.

Group dynamics: David tries to play the comedian. Gets a few laughs until the group confronts him about using humor to deflect real feelings. He eventually opens up about losing a close friend to overdose last year. Heavy stuff. The group urges him to hold space for grief without burying it in lines of coke.

David reveals he’s behind on rent and owes money to questionable 'friends.' Our case manager flags potential housing insecurity if he keeps funneling funds into recreational stimulants. Connecting him with local resources for financial counseling—shockingly, the 'friendship loan system' doesn’t comply with normal interest rate regulations. Time to get real with adulting.

David’s spouse attends. Tension city. She’s fed up with his 'youthful escapades' that put them both at risk. He half-apologizes but defaults to 'I’m stressed' as an excuse. The therapist calls him out, reminding him stress doesn’t justify turning their home into a revolving door of chaos. A progress plan emerges, but trust is fragile.

David’s nutritional status is 'vending-machine gourmet'—lots of junk, minimal produce. That plus stimulants has hammered his BMI down. We’re tossing him onto a balanced meal plan to stabilize energy levels and keep his mood from tanking. Not rocket science, but apparently new to him.

Psych doc prescribes a non-stimulant med to address possible ADHD and mood swings, to see if it curbs his 'need' for external uppers. He’s wary about meds—'I don’t want to rely on stuff'—the irony isn’t lost on anyone. We’ll monitor closely for any crossover cravings or negative side effects.

David’s partial hospitalization is wrapping up. Next steps: an intensive outpatient track with mandatory drug testing. Also recommended a local 'Stimulant Support' group—because step groups aren’t just for alcohol or opioids. He needs consistent accountability and peers who won’t blow smoke up his you-know-what.

David has shown improvement in honesty—less comedic deflection, more direct talk of triggers. He still teeters on the edge of 'party boy logic,' but acknowledges the dead-end nature of binging. Final discharge plan includes IOP, therapy, and follow-up psych visits. If he wants to avoid becoming a cautionary tale, it’s time to stay the course.
